docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Stephanie Hallberg was 16, she decided she wanted to reduce the size of her breasts. Ten years later and after visits with doctors -- all men, all of whom recommended she keep her breasts the way they were -- she found a doctor who sympathized with her predicament and agreed to perform the surgery, Dr. Michelle Copeland, who works out of a Fifth Avenue office complete with its own operating room and all-female staff, down to the anesthesiologist. ''I couldn't even imagine going to a man for any plastic surgery,'' Ms. Hallberg, 26, said. ''A man can study the woman's body forever, but I believe he can never really understand how a woman is put together, mentally, emotionally, physically.''

headline.main: Plastic Surgeons: Why So Few Women?

docs.abstract: Extreme dearth of women in field of cosmetic surgery discussed; women now comprise 46 percent of medical students, but only about four percent of all board-certified plastic surgeons in US, even though 89 percent of cosmetic-surgery patients are female; Dr Jane Petro cites 'Pygmalion angle,' pointing to large number of surgeons who end up, in second marriages, to former patients; long and intense training also makes it very difficult to balance work with family life; photo; hostile environment created by male surgeons in general also noted (M) plastic surgery training eight years after graduating from medical school, says long intense training makes it impossible to balance work and family or husband; hostile environment created by male surgeons in general also noted; photo of Dr Michelle

docs.lead_paragraph: Pumped up by the sort of foolishness that flourishes at bachelor parties as nowhere else, Jim Hamill and several buddies interrupted their weekend-long debauchery in Las Vegas to drive about an hour northeast to a dusty ranch here for what they expected to be the wildest, craziest adventure imaginable. Along with more than 600 other people, they entered a long, narrow pen this morning to be chased by, and run with, massive bulls weighing up to 1,500 pounds, an event meant to evoke the violent, sometimes lethal rampage every July in the streets of Pamplona, Spain. Mr. Hamill said he had figured it would be good for a flood of sweet adrenaline. But he was forced to make do with a trickle.

headline.main: Running of the Bull, American Style (i.e., Tame)

docs.abstract: About 600 people, mostly men aged 20 through 40, come to Mesquite, Nev, and pay $50 each to participate in what promoters hoped would be running of the bulls similar to event in Pamplona, Spain, each year; event turns out to be less than expected, as startled bulls rush right past runners, exhibiting little interest in anything other than meal at end of line; some animal rights activists call it cruel to try to incite bulls; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton said the Government would no longer do business with any health insurance company that flouts a 1996 law intended to guarantee access to coverage for people who change or lose their jobs. ''If you violate the letter or the spirit of the Kassebaum-Kennedy law, we will, if necessary, terminate your contract to provide health insurance to Federal employees,'' Mr. Clinton said. ''If you say no to people with pre-existing conditions, the Federal Government will say no to you.''

docs.lead_paragraph: Health plans cite lots of reasons for denying coverage of specific drugs and procedures. The procedure can be labeled cosmetic (breast reconstruction) or medically unnecessary (in-vitro fertilization). The remedy might be called experimental (bone marrow transplants) or dangerous (some diet pills). But there is one reason that health plans never cite: cost. Indeed, Dr. David Eddy, an expert on medical technology who advises many medical organizations including Kaiser Permanente, has coined the term ''cost taboo'' to express the prevailing notion that costs should not affect treatment decisions.

headline.main: Fallen Taboo: Frank Talk On Viagra Is About Cost

docs.abstract: Health insurer Kaiser Permanete has shattered taboo in case of Pfizer Inc's male impotence drug Viagra by frankly admitting cost is only factor in its decision to deny coverage; health insurers often restrict or exclude treatments because of costs without saying so; Kaiser's main problem is that it has no easy way to distinguish few males whose impotence is caused by physical malady from large number of men likely to demand drug; policy experts are split on ethics of stand (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal judges around the country, frustrated by cases in which patients denied medical benefits have no right to sue, are urging Congress to consider changes in a 1974 law that protects insurance companies and health maintenance organizations against legal attacks. In their decisions, the judges do not offer detailed solutions of the type being pushed in Congress by Democrats and some Republicans. But they say their hands are tied by the 1974 law, the Employee Retirement Income Security Act. And they often lament the results, saying the law has not kept pace with changes in health care and the workplace.

headline.main: Hands Tied, Judges Rue Law That Limits H.M.O. Liability

docs.abstract: Federal judges around nation, frustrated by cases in which patients improperly denied medical benefits by employer-sponsored health plans have no right to sue for resulting damages, are urging Congress to weigh changes in 1974 law that shields insurers and health maintenance organizations against liability suits; complain Employee Retirement Income Security Act has not kept pace with changes in health care and workplace; law established uniform Federal standards to spur employers to provide benefit (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Until just recently, the French motto seemed to be, ''I could have been a contender.'' Now France, for the first time, is a contender in a ''dream match'' against Brazil in the World Cup soccer championship final here on Sunday. Hundreds of thousands of delirious French fans celebrated the victory over Croatia Wednesday that got them into the finals by taking to the Champs-Elysees, demonstrating joie de vivre rather than the more usual griping they call ''la grogne.''

headline.main: Gallic Smiles Have Erased Gallic Gloom, for Now

docs.abstract: France's success so far in World Cup soccer play symbolizes nation's renewed optimism about economic outlook under Socialist Prime Min Lionel Jospin after long gloom; Jospin's poll ratings are his highest ever, while ratings of conservative Pres Jacques Chirac have also climbed; graphs of rises in gross domestic product and stock prices; photos (M)d

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-7 India-Pakistan Sanctions Would Exempt Food The Senate unanimously agreed to exempt food exports from sanctions that the United States imposed on India and Pakistan after those countries conducted nuclear tests in May, leaving almost no meaningful sanctions to punish the two nations. docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration has selected Dr. Jeffrey P. Koplan, an epidemiologist, as the next director of the Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. Dr. Koplan spent 22 years at the agency before leaving four years ago to run the research arm of Prudential Healthcare, one of the nation's largest health insurers. Donna E. Shalala, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, is expected to announce the appointment on Friday morning at the centers' headquarters in Atlanta, Administration officials said.

headline.main: Epidemiologist Is Chosen to Head Centers for Disease Control

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton selects Dr Jeffrey P Koplan, epidemiologist, as next director of Federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention; Koplan spent 22 years at agency before leaving four years ago; he replaces Dr David Satcher, who left in February to become Surgeon General (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Republican strategists conceded today that their party was vulnerable on managed-care legislation and needed to pass a credible bill before the November elections or risk political punishment. ''It's very important for Republicans not to come up with some token effort, because we are perceived as the party that doesn't care about the issue,'' said Rick Reed, a Republican media consultant who has worked on the managed-care issue. ''This issue can only intensify at this point.''

headline.main: G.O.P. at Risk If Health Bill Fails to Pass, Pollsters Say

docs.abstract: Republican strategists concede that their party is vulnerable on managed-care legislation and needs to pass credible bill before November elections or risk political punishment; Democrats in Senate are beginning to carry out their threat to attach their managed-care bill to essential spending bills (M)
